evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the historical dynamic understanding preliminary phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters, as alternative causes have been ruled out based on the evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 preliminary analysis.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, reflecting typical patterns of crew interaction failures.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical dynamic under preliminary data.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands potential defeaters based on the evidence and context provided in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical dynamic preliminary data.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features relevant to Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA operations as recorded in the specified historical dataset.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the historical dynamic understanding preliminary phase.

assumptions: The continued movement beyond TRP despite communication indicates coordination failure
No mechanical or environmental failures contributed significantly
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident
If mechanical failure or environmental factors were primary causes instead

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows communication among crew and tug operators, a decision to stop pushback, seat swapping, and eventual failure to stop at the TRP leading to collision, indicating observable communication/coordination breakdown supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether procedural deviation or communication breakdown was primary cause

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, reflecting typical patterns of crew interaction failures.

assumptions: The described crew interactions reflect communication/coordination breakdown patterns typical in such incidents.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and no coordination errors, or if mechanical or environmental factors were primary causes.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H1-H4) shows crew communication and coordination during pushback, including a trainee stopping and instructor taking over, and the aircraft overrunning the tug release point, consistent with typical crew interaction failures, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether the communication breakdown was the primary cause versus other factors like environment or mechanical issues.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical dynamic under preliminary data.

assumptions: The historical dynamic under preliminary data includes the described events in H4.
The procedural deviation is considered documented by the presence of this historical record.
defeaters: If evidence showed the aircraft stopped correctly at the TRP or if environmental markings were inadequate or misleading, this would change the assessment.
If mechanical control failure or communication breakdown evidence was present and explained the deviation, it would affect the conclusion.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly documents the procedural deviation in pushback execution by showing the aircraft moved beyond the designated Tug release point, supporting the claim of documented procedural deviation availability.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit mention of documentation location or format; assumption that historical dynamic under preliminary data includes this event.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features relevant to Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA operations as recorded in the specified historical dataset.

assumptions: No mechanical faults were detected or reported in the evidence; the described actions reflect procedural deviation rather than mechanical failure.
defeaters: If evidence of mechanical control failure or equipment fault traces were found, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H1-H4) describes the pushback procedure involving the tug instructor and trainee, the continuation beyond the TRP, and the collision with the blast barrier, indicating procedural deviation consistent with key features of Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA operations. The discriminator 'Equipment fault traces or bench checks separate control malfunction from operator procedural deviation' (disc:R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION|R4_MECHANICAL_CONTROL_FAILURE) is addressed by the absence of mechanical fault evidence and the described operator actions, favoring procedural deviation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters, as alternative causes have been ruled out based on the evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 preliminary analysis.

assumptions: The absence of mechanical fault evidence in the provided history implies mechanical failure is ruled out.
Communication and coordination issues are inferred from the sequence of events and crew interactions described.
defeaters: If evidence of hardware faults or mechanical control failures were found that could explain the event, this would challenge the communication breakdown explanation.
If new data showed that communication was effective and the cause was environmental or procedural, the defeater resistance claim would weaken.

The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

node.statement: Environmental and marking information was accessible and interpretable by the flight crew at the time of the event

The event outcome (passing TRP and hitting barrier) is due to factors other than marking availability or interpretability.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the markings were obscured, confusing, or not visible to the crew at the time, this would support environmental or marking deficiency.
If crew statements or recordings indicated inability to interpret or access marking information, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct contradictory evidence; minor ambiguity in exact communication quality but physical presence is clear.

If communication with the headset operator was lost or ineffective

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.
